chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;.
This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy &PRODNAME;, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.

chapter.title: Introduction to &PRODNAME; Deployment Strategies
chapter.para: You can deploy &PRODNAME; in either of two ways:

td.para: &PRODNAME; sits between the requester and the origin service.
&PRODNAME; runs on a different port or a different host than the origin service.
&PRODNAME; runs in the root context of the same application server as the origin service.
&PRODNAME; runs on the same port and host as the origin service.

chapter.para: This handbook is focused only on deployment strategies for &PRODNAME; itself. &PRODNAME; components are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: Default Configuration Model
chapter.para: We recommend that you deploy &PRODNAME; using the following operating systems, user and group configurations, and directories for configuration, artifacts, and deployment.

section.title: User and Group Configuration
section.para: Dedicate a user and group to &PRODNAME; to improve isolation of &PRODNAME;'s permissions. This user and group must be non-privileged; they can be assigned any valid name as long as their permissions are consistent.
Be sure the &PRODNAME; user and group can write to the file system as well as read configurations stored in the file system.

section.title: Configuration Directory
section.para: Store all of &PRODNAME;'s XML configurations in the configuration directory. The Root.War deployment assumes this directory is located in /etc/powerapi. &PRODNAME; only supports file system configuration locations.

section.title: Artifact Directory
section.para: An artifact may be a bundle of one or more components; an EAR is an example of an artifact.
In the artifact directory, store all the artifacts that &PRODNAME; has been configured to use.

section.title: Deployment Directory
section.para: Define a deployment directory as a writable location. &PRODNAME; uses the deployment directory to copy deployed versions of the artifacts it has been configured to use.

chapter.title: Artifacts
chapter.para: These artifacts are required for installation of &PRODNAME;.

td.para: All consumable artifacts meant for deployment through &PRODNAME; must conform to the Java Platform, Enterprise Edition 6 specification for Enterprise ARchive (EAR) files. For details, please read the Java EE 6 (JSR-316) specification at http://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=316.

The root.war artifact is a Web application ARchive (WAR). It contains all the components needed to install &PRODNAME; into a running application container. The WAR includes a default web.xml that can start up &PRODNAME; using the standard configuration model.

chapter.title: Deployment Configurations
chapter.para: We have provided XML samples to help explain the ideas in this section, but you must customize them to fit your own operating environment.
Configurations included in the WAR are deployed in the core of &PRODNAME;. For example, the power proxy and container configurations are within the scope of the core and are controlled by root.war.
&PRODNAME; core configurations outline the deployment layout for the service cluster and tell the system where to look for component artifacts.
Configurations included in the EAR are deployed as components. For example, the versioning configuration is a component, outside the scope of the core and controlled by the EAR.

section.title: Configuration Directory: Power Proxy
section.para: The power proxy configuration is the &PRODNAME; system model. This configuration outlines the entire deployment layout for the service cluster. &PRODNAME; must be aware of this in order to configure itself and correctly coordinate routing if necessary.

The system model also lets &PRODNAME; know where the other &PRODNAME; nodes reside. Using this information, &PRODNAME; can coordinate its own clustering to help balance load or share data among nodes that share common filters.

section.title: Container Configuration
section.para: The container configuration in &PRODNAME; is used to tell the system where to look for component artifacts and where to deploy them. The deployment directory's configuration element includes an attribute that tells &PRODNAME; whether or not it should clean up deployed artifacts once they're no longer in use. In addition, the artifact directory's configuration element includes an optional attribute that can be used to tweak the polling interval. Based on the polling interval, &PRODNAME; checks for modified, deleted, or new artifacts.
To integrate &PRODNAME;with Apache Tomcat, you must add this line to context.xml: <context crosscontext="true">.

note.para: For Tomcat 7, context.xml is found in /var/lib/tomcat7/config/context.xml.
